item.title: Even Low Levels of ctDNA May Be Linked to Recurrence Risk in Early Lung Cancer, Study Finds - The ASCO Post
item.description:
Even Low Levels of ctDNA May Be Linked to Recurrence Risk in Early Lung Cancer, Study Finds

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Nature Medicine

Lung cancer, the second most common cancer in the U.S., has high recurrence rates in early-stage patients. A new study indicates that low levels of circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) are associated with an increased risk of recurrence in early-stage lung adenocarcinoma, pointing to the potential for personalized genomic testing.

  • The study was based on the TRACERx cohort of 171 patients with early-stage lung cancer.
  • NeXT Personal, a sensitive genomic test, was used to analyze blood samples for ctDNA levels.
  • Results showed that patients with < 80 ppm ctDNA had reduced overall survival.
  • Positive ctDNA detection correlated with a high recurrence risk, even at low levels.
“This study demonstrates the potential of using more sensitive ctDNA tests like NeXT Personal in detecting lung cancer.” - Charles Swanton

The findings underscore the importance of sensitive ctDNA testing for personalizing lung cancer treatment and improving patient outcomes.

item.title: It's possible to erase bad memories; scientists discover how - The Times of India
item.description:
It's Possible to Erase Bad Memories; Scientists Discover How

Publication Date: N/A Source: N/A

This article discusses a groundbreaking study that suggests it's feasible to erase bad memories using targeted scientific techniques, potentially paving the way for new therapeutic methods.

  • Researchers have identified specific neural pathways that can be altered to diminish the impact of negative memories.
  • The study opens up possibilities for treating conditions like PTSD and anxiety disorders.
  • Ethical considerations of memory alteration are discussed, emphasizing the importance of consent and potential unforeseen consequences.
“The ability to modify or erase memories could be revolutionary in the treatment of mental health disorders,” said a lead researcher.

This discovery marks a significant step in neuroscience and psychology, raising questions about the future of memory treatment.

item.title: 10 morning habits to keep the kidneys in good health - The Times of India
item.description:
10 Morning Habits to Keep the Kidneys Healthy

Publication Date: Jan 14, 2025 | Source: Times of India

This article discusses simple yet effective habits to enhance kidney health, emphasizing the importance of routine practices like hydration and balanced meals in maintaining good kidney function.

  • Drink water first thing in the morning to rehydrate.
  • Engage in regular exercise to support kidney health.
  • Consume kidney-friendly foods like berries and leafy greens.
  • Eat a balanced breakfast rich in nutrients.
  • Take probiotics or herbal teas to promote kidney function.
  • Monitor blood sugar levels to protect kidney health.
  • Maintain healthy blood pressure through yoga or meditation.
  • Avoid excessive caffeine intake to prevent dehydration.
  • Practice deep breathing exercises to relieve stress.
  • Limit salt intake to reduce strain on the kidneys.
“Starting your day with healthy habits can significantly boost kidney function.” - TOI Lifestyle Desk

In conclusion, integrating these morning habits can lead to improved kidney health and overall well-being.

item.title: AI reveals key follicle sizes to boost IVF success - News-Medical.Net
item.description:
AI Reveals Key Follicle Sizes to Boost IVF Success

Publication Date: January 14, 2025 | Source: News-Medical

A recent study utilizes explainable artificial intelligence (XAI) to identify follicle sizes important for optimizing outcomes in assisted conception, particularly in vitro fertilization (IVF).

  • One in six couples globally faces infertility, a serious disability as defined by WHO.
  • XAI enhances the quality of personalized ART treatments by managing complex datasets.
  • Data was collected from 19,082 female participants in Poland and the UK between 2005-2023.
  • Optimal follicle sizes identified range from 13 to 20 mm for mature oocyte collection.
  • Findings show that intermediately sized follicles significantly enhance oocyte retrieval and embryo development.
“Intermediately sized follicles on the DoT were found to significantly contribute to the retrieval of mature oocytes and embryo development.”

This study highlights the potential of XAI techniques in optimizing IVF treatments, leading to better clinical outcomes.

item.title: What’s Going Around Right Now? The 4 Winter Viruses of the ‘Quad-Demic,’ Explained - Health.com
item.description:
What's Going Around Right Now? The 4 Winter Viruses of the 'Quad-Demic,' Explained

Date: January 5, 2025

Source: Health

Four illnesses are circulating at high levels this winter, leading to a 'quad-demic' in the U.S., significantly affecting public health and healthcare systems.

  • COVID-19, Influenza, RSV, and Norovirus are the major viruses currently affecting the population.
  • The CDC reports a record number of norovirus outbreaks this season.
  • Healthcare systems are strained due to the simultaneous spread of these viruses.
“It [has] a huge impact, not just on the individual who’s sick, but on the community.” - Geeta Sood, MD

Experts encourage individuals to take precautions, especially those who are at higher risk, to stay healthy this winter.

item.title: What’s behind joint pains this winter? Orthos and nutritionists tell you how to keep moving despite them - The Indian Express
item.description:
What’s behind joint pains this winter? Orthos and nutritionists tell you how to keep moving despite them

Date: January 13, 2025

Source: Indian Express

As the winter chill sets in, many people experience stiff and painful joints, limiting their ability to exercise. Experts explain that the cold can exacerbate swelling in tissues and bones, resulting in a decrease in range of motion and an increase in discomfort.

  • The cold can limit movement due to joint stiffness and pain.
  • Exposure to cold leads to constriction of blood vessels, reducing blood flow to limbs.
  • Swelling in bones and tissues during cold weather can increase discomfort.
"Is the cold limiting your movement because of stiff and painful joints?"

Understanding these factors is essential for managing and mitigating joint pain during the winter months.

item.title: Why do headaches worsen in the winter season? 5 remedies to treat them - The Times of India
item.description:
Why do headaches worsen in the winter season? 5 remedies to treat them

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

Headaches often intensify during the winter months due to various factors including changes in temperature and humidity. This article provides insights into why this happens and suggests five remedies to alleviate headache pain.

  • Winter weather can trigger headaches due to low pressure and cold temperatures.
  • Common types of winter headaches include sinus headaches and tension headaches.
  • Staying hydrated is crucial as dehydration can worsen headaches.
  • Over-the-counter pain relievers and rest can be effective treatments.
  • Consulting a healthcare professional is recommended for severe or persistent headaches.
“Headaches can be a common winter complaint, but understanding the triggers can help in managing them effectively.”

In conclusion, recognizing the winter triggers of headaches and employing these remedies can significantly help in managing discomfort during the colder months.

item.title: Want to stop smoking? $700 in rewards can really help, study says - The Jerusalem Post
item.description:
Want to stop smoking? $700 in rewards can really help, study says

Publication Date: JANUARY 14, 2025

Source: The Jerusalem Post

This article discusses a study led by the University of East Anglia that investigates the effectiveness of monetary rewards in aiding individuals, particularly pregnant women, to quit smoking. The findings suggest that financial incentives significantly improve cessation rates.

  • A collaborative study involving the University of East Anglia, University of Oxford, University of Edinburgh, and University of Massachusetts Amherst.
  • Research explored the effects of cash, vouchers, or deposits as incentives.
  • Results indicate that rewards increased the likelihood of quitting smoking among participants.
  • High certainty evidence shows that incentives are effective for pregnant women, with a greater success rate.
  • The study examined 48 prior studies with over 21,900 participants and found consistent results.
  • Success rates hold even after rewards are stopped.
“These findings show that financial incentives during pregnancy can more than double the chances of quitting smoking.” - Professor Linda Bauld

The study implies ongoing support for incentive schemes for smoking cessation, particularly for vulnerable populations like pregnant women.

item.title: Deadly 'zombie deer' disease could evolve to affect humans, warn scientists - The Times of India
item.description:
Deadly 'zombie deer' disease could evolve to affect humans, warn scientists

Publication Date: [Date not provided] Source: Daily Mail

Scientists have issued a warning that the incurable prion disease, known as the 'zombie deer' disease, could potentially evolve to affect humans, posing a serious threat of a new pandemic.

  • The disease, known scientifically as Chronic Wasting Disease (CWD), primarily affects deer and related species.
  • There are concerns it could jump to feral pigs and possibly domestic swine, affecting the swine market.
  • Symptoms include drooling, confusion, aggression, and weight loss, appearing about a year after infection.
  • Currently reported in at least 33 states, including Wyoming, Wisconsin, Colorado, and areas of Pennsylvania.
  • Health officials emphasize the importance of awareness, as the disease can spread through bodily fluids.
Dr. Michael Osterholm stated, "If they can get infected, surely it's possible domestic swine could also become infected? What would that do to the swine market? What would that do to the cattle market? These are huge issues."

Scientists stress the urgency of understanding and preparing for potential health crises that could arise from this disease spreading to humans.

item.title: Iron next in line for fortification focus - FoodNavigator.com
item.description:
Iron Next in Line for Fortification Focus

Publication Date: October 2024 | Source: Food Navigator

This article discusses the increasing trends in women's health focusing on iron fortification in food and beverages, spurred by new research emphasizing the importance of iron during pregnancy.

  • The global market for women's health has reached $35.02bn and is expected to grow.
  • Research indicates that iron deficiency in pregnant women is a critical health concern, affecting around 32 million women worldwide.
  • A third-trimester iron infusion has been shown to significantly reduce anaemia.
  • The World Health Organization recommends oral iron tablets for pregnant women, but fortified foods could offer an alternative solution.
  • The fortified food market is valued at $103.54bn, driven by consumer demand for nutrient-enhanced products.
“While anaemia is one of the most avoidable causes of illness and death in resource-poor nations, any woman across the world can become anaemic during pregnancy.” - Professor Sant-Rayn Pasricha

The focus on iron fortification reflects a growing awareness of nutritional needs during pregnancy and could lead to innovative product development in the food industry.

item.title: Asymptomatic lung abscess of aspergillus in a female without previous lung diseases or immunocompromise: a case report - BMC Infectious Diseases
item.description:
Asymptomatic lung abscess of aspergillus in a female without previous lung diseases or immunocompromise: a case report

Published: 14 January 2025 | Source: BMC Infectious Diseases

This case report documents an unusual occurrence of a chronic lung abscess due to Aspergillus terreus in a 43-year-old female patient without immunocompromise or any structural lung disease, illustrating significant challenges in diagnosis due to the absence of symptoms.

  • The patient had a mass shadow detected on CT imaging without respiratory complaints.
  • 30 ml of purulent fluid aspirated from the lung confirmed an Aspergillus terreus infection.
  • Standard antifungal treatment resulted in a favorable outcome.
“Aspergillus lung abscess can occasionally occur in a person without pre-existent lung cavity and immune suppression.”

This case highlights the complexity of diagnosing fungal infections, especially in asymptomatic patients, and urges careful consideration of laboratory methods like mNGS for accurate identification.

item.title: American Medical Association suggests realistic health goals in 2025 - Medical Xpress
item.description:
American Medical Association Suggests Realistic Health Goals for 2025

Date: January 14, 2025, Source: Atlanta Journal-Constitution

As the new year approaches, the American Medical Association (AMA) encourages people to set effective wellness goals through simple, sustainable changes.

  • Move more, watch less: Substitute screen time with daily walks; aim for 150 minutes of moderate activity weekly.
  • Sayonara, processed foods: Turn meal prep into a family bonding experience to promote better dietary choices.
  • Prioritize quality rest: Aim for at least 7.5 hours of sleep per night and manage stress effectively.
  • Tech-smart health monitoring: Utilize validated health devices and online health screening tools to monitor health more effectively.
"Even small, positive choices you make now can have a big impact on your long-term well-being." - AMA President Bruce A. Scott

In summary, the AMA's suggestions focus on attainable habits to enhance overall health and well-being in 2025.

item.title: As avian influenza A(H5N1) concerns continue, mRNA vaccines offer great potential - Clinical Trials Arena
item.description:
mRNA Vaccines Show Promise Against Avian Influenza A(H5N1)

Date: January 14, 2025 | Source: GlobalData Healthcare

With avian influenza A(H5N1) cases rising among cattle and humans in the US, mRNA vaccine technology offers a rapid response option for future pandemics.

  • H5N1 virus is a highly pathogenic avian influenza affecting wild birds and poultry.
  • Since March 2024, there is a multistate outbreak among dairy cattle across 16 states.
  • 66 confirmed human cases of H5N1 were reported in the US in 2024.
  • The first human death due to H5N1 in the US was recorded in January 2025.
  • CDC is closely monitoring H5N1 outbreaks and outbreaks among humans.
  • 12 vaccines for H5N1 are currently in clinical development, five of which utilize mRNA technology.
  • The BARDA is supporting the development of H5N1 vaccines, diagnostics, and therapeutics.
“The implementation of pandemic preparedness measures, specifically the development of H5N1 mRNA vaccines, offers great potential to mitigate a future pandemic.”

The potential development of mRNA H5N1 vaccines could significantly improve global pandemic preparedness.

item.title: Vaccination status and hepatitis A immunity in children: insights from a large-scale study in Turkey - BMC Infectious Diseases
item.description:
Vaccination status and hepatitis A immunity in children: insights from a large-scale study in Turkey

Published: 14 January 2025 | Source: BMC Infectious Diseases

This research examines the hepatitis A vaccination status and the corresponding immunity levels in Turkish children. It highlights significant disparities in seropositivity rates among different age groups and vaccination categories.

  • Study involved 9,858 pediatric patients aged 6 months to 18 years.
  • Seropositivity rates were 93% for fully vaccinated, 83% for single-dose vaccinated, and 63% for unvaccinated children.
  • The majority of children (60.5%) were fully vaccinated, while 35% were unvaccinated.
  • Antibody levels showed a significant decrease with age in unvaccinated individuals.
“These findings underscore the critical need for targeted interventions to close vaccination gaps.”

This study provides essential data to enhance public health strategies and vaccination programs against hepatitis A in Turkey.

item.title: British-Indian Trump doctor spills diet secrets that reverse prediabetes, lower BP in days - Hindustan Times
item.description:
British-Indian Doctor Reveals Metabolic Reset Diet to Combat Prediabetes and High Blood Pressure

Publication Date: January 2025

Source: Hindustan Times

Dr Aseem Malhotra introduces a simple five-ingredient diet aimed at reversing prediabetes and lowering blood pressure within days, with a focus on whole, unprocessed foods.

  • The diet prohibits items with five or more ingredients.
  • It aims to eliminate junk food addiction and reset metabolic health.
  • Patients reported improvements in prediabetes and blood pressure within 28 days.
  • The diet allows for gradual reintroduction of carbohydrates after a month.
  • Beverages are limited to zero-calorie options and moderate alcohol consumption.
  • The upcoming online program begins on February 10, 2025.
“We don’t want people to feel hungry.” - Dr Aseem Malhotra

This diet is positioned as an effective and sustainable solution for individuals looking to manage their health through dietary changes.

item.title: Respiratory illnesses are up nationwide: Here are the COVID, flu and RSV hotspots - Medical Xpress
item.description:
Respiratory illnesses are up nationwide: Here are the COVID, flu and RSV hotspots

Publication Date: January 14, 2025 | Source: The Charlotte Observer

Respiratory illnesses, including COVID-19, flu, and RSV, are surging across the United States, with many states now classified as national hotspots.

  • The CDC reported a "high" level of respiratory illness activity as of January 13.
  • Arizona, Oklahoma, Kentucky, Hawaii, Delaware, and New Hampshire are experiencing the highest case numbers.
  • COVID-19 activity is increasing, particularly due to new variants, but its overall cases are currently considered low compared to flu and RSV.
  • The increase in respiratory cases is particularly alarming among children under the age of 4.
  • Vaccination rates for COVID-19 and flu remain low, contributing to the rise in cases.
“Vaccination coverage with influenza and COVID-19 vaccines are low among U.S. adults and children,” the CDC stated.

With increasing hospitalizations expected this respiratory season, health officials emphasize the importance of vaccination and monitoring the spread of these illnesses.

item.title: MGM Hospital Jamshedpur prepares ward for HMPV patients - Avenue Mail
item.description:
MGM Hospital Jamshedpur Prepares Ward for HMPV Patients

Publication Date: Not specified | Source: The Avenue Mail

MGM Hospital has established a dedicated ward to treat patients suffering from the Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV), emphasizing preparedness amid rising concerns from social media.

  • A new ward equipped with an oxygen pipeline has been set up on the third floor.
  • Staff are urged to wear masks, use sanitizers, and maintain distance from symptomatic patients.
  • No cases of HMPV have been reported yet at MGM Hospital.
  • ICMR has instructed the hospital to test five patients weekly for HMPV.
  • There is a surge in demand for sanitizers and masks in the local area.
“Department heads suggested setting up a ward equipped with oxygen and ensuring the availability of masks, gloves, and sanitizers,” said Dr Rani.

Dr Balram Jha reassures that HMPV is not particularly dangerous and likens it to a viral cold with prolonged coughing.

item.title: Effects of Empagliflozin on Uric Acid and Gout in CKD - DocWire News
item.description:
Effects of Empagliflozin on Uric Acid and Gout in CKD

Publication Date: N/A Source: Nephrology Dialysis Transplantation

This article discusses the findings of researchers exploring the effects of SGLT2 inhibition on uric acid levels and gout incidence in chronic kidney disease patients, based on data from the EMPA-KIDNEY trial.

  • Study involved 6,609 patients with CKD randomized to empagliflozin or placebo over two years.
  • Mean serum uric acid concentration was reduced by 25.6 µmol/L in the empagliflozin group.
  • No significant reduction in gout events compared to placebo was observed.
  • Effects were more pronounced in non-diabetic patients and those with higher eGFR.
“SGLT2 inhibition reduces serum uric acid in patients with CKD with larger effects at higher eGFR and in the absence of diabetes. However, the effect on uric acid is modest and did not translate into reduced risk of gout in EMPA-KIDNEY.”

Despite reducing uric acid levels, empagliflozin does not significantly decrease the risk of gout among CKD patients.

item.title: Press Ganey Expands AI Capabilities to Transform Safety and the Experience of Patients and Healthcare Employees - Business Wire
item.description:
Press Ganey Expands AI Capabilities to Transform Safety and the Experience of Patients and Healthcare Employees

Date: CHICAGO

Source: BUSINESS WIRE

Press Ganey, the leading provider of experience measurement, data analytics, and insights for health systems and health plans, today unveiled expanded AI capabilities designed to help healthcare leaders anticipate challenges, take proactive action, and improve safety and experiences for patients and employees.

“With these expanded capabilities, Press Ganey AI ensures that organizations can act with confidence, leveraging technology that prioritizes safety, accuracy, and equity to improve outcomes for patients and employees alike.”

Key Features of Press Ganey AI:

  • AI Summarize: Extract insights rapidly by analyzing feedback.
  • AI Compose: Generate context-aware responses to enhance patient feedback collection.
  • AI Recommend: Use predictive analytics to address safety and engagement risks.

Healthcare organizations that utilize Press Ganey’s AI solutions have reported significant improvements in identifying at-risk patients and streamlining processes.

“AI has the potential to revolutionize healthcare by providing leaders with the tools to predict and address challenges before they arise,” said Darren Dworkin, President and Chief Operating Officer of Press Ganey.

item.title: Frustrated with low income? Study says this habit may be the unseen culprit - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Smoking May Be Impacting Your Income, Study Finds

Date: Jan 14, 2025 | Source: Hindustan Times

A new study published in the journal Nicotine & Tobacco Research highlights the hidden economic costs of smoking, revealing a correlation between smoking habits and lower earnings, particularly among less educated individuals.

  • The study examined data from 3,596 participants in Finland.
  • Each 1-pack-year increase in smoking is associated with a 1.8% decrease in earnings.
  • Participants who reduced their smoking by five pack-years could see a potential 9% increase in earnings.
  • The findings suggest that smoking disproportionately affects younger, less educated workers.
  • There is less impact noticed on older workers.
“Smoking leads to low income, especially for young people from low educational backgrounds, as they may be in jobs that require physical work.”

In conclusion, while smoking has well-documented health risks, this study adds an economic perspective to the dangers of smoking, revealing its potential to adversely affect income levels.

item.title: Effective ways to relieve lower back pain during periods - The Indian Express
item.description:
Effective Ways to Relieve Lower Back Pain During Periods

Published on: Unknown date Source: The Indian Express

This article discusses various methods to alleviate lower back pain often experienced during menstruation. It suggests exercises, dietary adjustments, and lifestyle changes that can help.

  • Regular exercise improves flexibility and strengthens core muscles, reducing lower back pain.
  • Incorporating deep breathing techniques, meditation, and mild stretches can relieve tension and discomfort.
  • Yoga poses such as Ushtrasana and Bhujangasana strengthen lower back muscles and mitigate pain.
  • Reducing caffeine and salty meals can help prevent bloating that exacerbates back pain.
  • A diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and omega-3 fatty acids can lower inflammation.
  • Wearing loose-fitting clothing can enhance comfort and reduce strain during periods.
"Regular exercise helps to increase flexibility and strengthen core muscles, which can greatly lessen lower back pain during menstruation."

This article provides practical solutions for managing lower back pain during menstruation, emphasizing the importance of physical activity and dietary choices for overall comfort.

item.title: Fibre in diet can reduce risk of gut infections: 6 ways to add more fibre in meals - The Times of India
item.description:
Fibre in diet can reduce risk of gut infections: 6 ways to add more fibre in meals

Publication Date: October 2023

Source: Health Wellness Journal

Fibre is essential for digestive health, and a diet high in fibre can significantly lower the risk of gut infections. Here are six effective ways to incorporate more fibre into meals.

  • Include fruits and vegetables in every meal.
  • Opt for whole grain products over refined grains.
  • Add legumes such as beans and lentils to dishes.
  • Snacks on nuts and seeds instead of processed foods.
  • Incorporate more high-fibre cereals into breakfast.
  • Experiment with fibre-rich recipes.
"A diet rich in fibre is crucial for maintaining gut health and preventing infections," says a nutrition expert.

In conclusion, enhancing your diet with more fibre can lead to better gut health and overall well-being.

item.title: Obese children face heightened risk of relapse post-cancer diagnosis - The Jerusalem Post
item.description:
Obese Children Face Increased Risk of Cancer Relapse and Mortality

Date: January 14, 2025 Source: Jpost

Obesity in children diagnosed with cancer poses significant health risks, highlighting the importance of managing obesity to improve cancer outcomes.

  • Study conducted by researchers at Montreal's Sainte-Justine Hospital.
  • Data analyzed from the Cancer in Young People in Canada database (2001-2020).
  • 10.5% of 11,291 children with cancer were classified as obese.
  • Obese children had lower rates of 5-year event-free survival (77.5% vs 79.6%) and overall survival (83.0% vs 85.9%).
  • Obesity linked to a 16% increased risk of cancer relapse and a 29% increased risk of death.
  • Most pronounced effects observed in patients with acute lymphoblastic leukemia and brain tumors.
“Our study highlights the negative impact of obesity among all types of childhood cancers. It provides the rationale to evaluate different strategies to mitigate the adverse risk of obesity on cancer outcomes in future trials,” said co-senior author Thai Hoa Tran, MD.

This study underscores the urgent need to address childhood obesity, which can have serious health implications for affected children.

item.title: Eyes give these early symptoms of cancer and diabetes: Know more - Onmanorama
item.description:
Eyes Give These Early Symptoms of Cancer and Diabetes: Know More

Published: January 14, 2025

The article discusses how the eyes can reveal early signs of serious health conditions such as diabetes, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, and certain cancer types. It emphasizes the importance of eye health in diagnosing these diseases early.

  • Poets claim eyes convey emotions, but they can also show early disease signs.
  • 25% of type 1 and 40% of type 2 diabetic patients may have eye defects.
  • High blood pressure symptoms visible in the eyes include prominent blood vessels.
  • High cholesterol can lead to health issues in the eye like Hollenhorst plague.
  • Retinoblastoma, affecting eyes, can spread to other organs.
  • Eyes offer clues for serious ailments like brain tumors.
  • Symptoms like unusual eye movements warrant immediate medical attention.
“These symptoms in the eyes may be signs of underlying diseases that should not be ignored.”

In conclusion, maintaining eye health is crucial for early diagnosis of severe health issues. Regular eye checks can help identify potential health risks before they become critical.
